textfield.text: Course Description
Cover Principles and Practice of Computer Networking (Emphasis on Internet Services)

textfield.text: Computer Network:
Collection of Computers and other devices or peripherals, connected together through Connecting Media

P.FONT: Collection of Computers and other devices or peripherals, connected together through Connecting Media

textfield.text: Peripheral Device:

A computer device, such as a CD-ROM drive or printer, that is not part of the essential computer, i.e., the memory and microprocessor. Peripheral devices can be external -- such as a mouse, keyboard, printer, monitor, external Zip drive or scanner -- or internal, such as a CD-ROM drive, CD-R drive or internal modem. Internal peripheral devices are often referred to as integrated peripherals. Source: WebOpedia "http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/P/peripheral_device.html"

P.FONT:
A computer device, such as a CD-ROM drive or printer, that is not part of the essential computer, i.e., the memory and microprocessor. Peripheral devices can be external -- such as a mouse, keyboard, printer, monitor, external Zip drive or scanner -- or internal, such as a CD-ROM drive, CD-R drive or internal modem. Internal peripheral devices are often referred to as integrated peripherals. Source: WebOpedia "
http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/P/peripheral_device.html
"

textfield.text: Benifits of Computer Networks
Resource Sharing
File Sharing
Peripheral Sharing
Software Sharing with Multi-user Liscence
Computers / Peripherals
NIC (Network Interface Card) The hardware that plugs into the motherboard and directly access the network

P.FONT: The hardware that plugs into the motherboard and directly access the network

textfield.text: Hub: Allow different nodes to communicate with each other

textfield.text: Switch: Allow different nodes to communicate with each other at the same time without slowing each other down.

Networking Devices

textfield.text: Lesson 2
Lesson 3: Classificatios of Networks
Group of computers connected in small geographical area Allow users to share files and services

LI.FONT: Group of computers connected in
Allow users to share files and services

textfield.text: Group of computers connected in Large geographical area such as country Often connects two LANs (WAN Link)

LI.FONT: Group of computers connected in Large geographical area such as country
Often connects two LANs (WAN Link)

textfield.text: connects an area larger than a LAN but smaller than a WAN, such as a city.

P.FONT: connects an area larger than a LAN but

textfield.text: All computers are considered equal They all have the same abilities to use the resources available on the network. Example : Windows Workgroup (file and print sharing) computers can act both as a client and a server Also referred to as peers.

LI.FONT: All computers are considered equal
They all have the same abilities to use the resources available on the network.
Example : Windows Workgroup (file and print sharing)
computers can act both as a client and a server
Also referred to as peers.

textfield.text: Some nodes (SERVER) are dedicated to present services to other nodes (CLIENTS) The computers providing the service are called servers Computers that request and use the service are called client computers. Examples: Mail Server, Web Serve, File Server

LI.FONT: Some nodes (SERVER) are dedicated to present services to other nodes (CLIENTS)
The computers providing the service are called servers
Computers that request and use the service are called client computers.
Examples: Mail Server, Web Serve, File Server

textfield.text: First, client initiates a request sent to a certain server, then the server replies with the service required to the client. There are many clients and one server, (actually, the number of servers is very small compared with the number of clients)

LI.FONT: First, client initiates a request sent to a certain server, then the server replies with the service required to the client.
There are many clients and one server, (actually, the number of servers is very small compared with the number of clients)

textfield.text: Topology refers to the shape of a network, or the network's layout. Topology: how, and in what shape, network components are connected together Each topology is suited to specific tasks and has its own advantages and disadvantages. How different nodes in a network are connected to each other and how they communicate are determined by the network's topology. The choice of topology is dependent upon: 1. Type and number of equipment being used 2.Cost

LI.FONT: Topology refers to the shape of a network, or the network's layout.
Topology: how, and in what shape, network components are connected together
Each topology is suited to specific tasks and has its own advantages and disadvantages.
How different nodes in a network are connected to each other and how they communicate are determined by the network's topology.
The choice of topology is dependent upon:

P.FONT: 1. Type and number of equipment being used

textfield.text: Bus Topology

All devices are connected to a central cable, called the bus or backbone. Both ends of the network must be terminated with a terminator. A parrel connector can be used to extend the network. The backbone functions as a shared communication medium Device wanting to communicate with another device on the network sends a message onto the backbone. The message is heard by all stations, but only the intended recipient actually accepts and processes the message. Terminator absorbs frames at end of medium.

LI.FONT: All devices are connected to a central cable, called the bus or backbone.
Both ends of the network must be terminated with a terminator.
A parrel connector can be used to extend the network.
The backbone functions as a shared communication medium
Device wanting to communicate with another device on the network sends a message onto the backbone.
The message is heard by all stations, but only the intended recipient actually accepts and processes the message.
Terminator absorbs frames at end of medium.

textfield.text: Bus Topology
Star Topology
A physical Star topology connects the devices via a centralized unit such as a Hub or Switch. Nodes communicate across the network by passing data through the central device.

LI.FONT: A physical Star topology connects the devices via a centralized unit such as a Hub or Switch.
Nodes communicate across the network by passing data through the central device.

textfield.text: Star Topology

Single computer failure doesnt bring down whole network Adding new devices to a Star network is very simple compared to any of the other topologies No disruptions to the network when connecting or removing devices. Centralized control Centralized network/hub monitoring Easy to troubleshoot

LI.FONT: Single computer failure doesnt bring down whole network
Adding new devices to a Star network is very simple compared to any of the other topologies
No disruptions to the network when connecting or removing devices.
Centralized control
Centralized network/hub monitoring
Easy to troubleshoot

textfield.text: If central device fails, the whole network fails Compared to the bus topology, a star network generally requires more cable More expensive than linear bus topologies because of the cost of the central device

LI.FONT: If central device fails, the whole network fails
Compared to the bus topology, a star network generally requires more cable
More expensive than linear bus topologies because of the cost of the central device

textfield.text: Ring Topology

All devices are connected to one another in the shape of a closed loop, so that each device is connected directly to two other devices, one on either side of it. Data is passed one way from device to device.

LI.FONT: All devices are connected to one another in the shape of a closed loop, so that each device is connected directly to two other devices, one on either side of it.
Data is passed one way from device to device.

textfield.text: Perform well under heavy traffic.
If one device/cable fails then the whole network goes down. Difficult to troubleshoot Adding/Removing computers disrupts the whole network

LI.FONT: If one device/cable fails then the whole network goes down.
Difficult to troubleshoot
Adding/Removing computers disrupts the whole network

textfield.text: Mesh Topology
In a mesh topology each device/PC is connected to every other device/PC in the network by its own cable

P.FONT: In a mesh topology each device/PC is connected to every other device/PC in the network by its own cable

textfield.text: Full Mesh
Partial Mesh
Mesh topology boasts the highest fault tolerance of all of the network topologies

P.FONT: Mesh topology boasts the highest fault tolerance of all of the network topologies

textfield.text: Because each connection needs its own cable a Mesh topology can get very expensive.

P.FONT: Because each connection needs its own cable a Mesh topology can get very expensive.

textfield.text: Hybrid Topology
Hybrid means that there is more than one topology exist

P.FONT: Hybrid means that there is more than one topology exist

textfield.text: Groups of star-configured networks are connected to a linear bus backbone

P.FONT: Groups of star-configured networks are connected to a linear bus backbone

textfield.text: Network expansion is simple
If hub fails connections between failed hub and other hubs will fail

P.FONT: If hub fails connections between failed hub and other hubs will fail

textfield.text: Lesson 4: Network Transmission Media
To transmit data, a medium must exist The medium can be in the form of cables or wireless medium

LI.FONT: To transmit data, a medium must exist
The medium can be in the form of cables or wireless medium

textfield.text: There are several types of cable which are commonly used with LANs. In some cases, a network will utilize only one type of cable, other networks will use a variety of cable types. The type of cable chosen for a network is related to the network's topology, protocol, and size.

LI.FONT: There are several types of cable which are commonly used with LANs.
In some cases, a network will utilize only one type of cable, other networks will use a variety of cable types.
The type of cable chosen for a network is related to the network's topology, protocol, and size.

textfield.text: The principle upon which the UTP cables are classified is the amount of twisting, when the twisting amount is increased, the interference amount is decreased, . as a final result, the bandwidth the cable support increases

P.FONT: The principle upon which the UTP cables are classified is the amount of twisting, when the twisting amount is increased, the interference amount is decreased, . as a final result, the bandwidth the cable support increases

textfield.text: Category 3 UTP
Category 5 UTP
STP is similar to UTP, but it has an outer layer to protect the cable from the surrounding noise, so it carries more bandwidth

P.FONT: STP is similar to UTP, but it has an outer layer to protect the cable from the surrounding noise, so it carries more bandwidth

textfield.text: Lesson 1: Introduction to OSI Model
OSI: Open Systems Interconnection

OSI model is the primary architectural model for networks. It describes how data and network information are communicated from an application on one computer, through the network media, to an application on another computer. The model was defined by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) The OSI reference model breaks this approach into layers

LI.FONT: OSI model is the primary architectural model for networks.
It describes how data and network information are communicated from an application on one computer, through the network media, to an application on another computer.
The model was defined by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO)
The OSI reference model breaks this approach into layers

textfield.text: Advantages of Reference Model

It divides the network communication process into smaller and simpler components, thus aiding component development, design, and troubleshooting. It allows multiple-vendor development through standardization of network components. It encourages industry standardization by defining what functions occur at each layer of the model. It allows various types of network hardware and software to communicate. It prevents changes in one layer from affecting other layers, so it does not hamper development.

LI.FONT: It divides the network communication process into smaller and simpler components, thus aiding component development, design, and troubleshooting.
It allows multiple-vendor development through standardization of network components.
It encourages industry standardization by defining what functions occur at each layer of the model.
It allows various types of network hardware and software to communicate.
It prevents changes in one layer from affecting other layers, so it does not hamper development.

textfield.text: Lesson 2: Application Layer

Provides a means for the user to access information on the network through an application. This layer is the main interface for the user(s) to interact with the application and therefore the network. Displays received information and sends data to lower layers.

LI.FONT: Provides a means for the user to access information on the network through an application.
This layer is the main interface for the user(s) to interact with the application and therefore the network.
Displays received information and sends data to lower layers.

textfield.text: Lesson 3: Presentation Layer

The presentation layer is responsible for the delivery and formatting of information to the application layer for further processing or display. It relieves the application layer of concern regarding syntactical differences in data representation within the end-user systems. An example of a presentation service would be the conversion of an EBCDIC-coded text file to an ASCII-coded file.

LI.FONT: The presentation layer is responsible for the delivery and formatting of information to the application layer for further processing or display.
It relieves the application layer of concern regarding syntactical differences in data representation within the end-user systems.
An example of a presentation service would be the conversion of an EBCDIC-coded text file to an ASCII-coded file.

textfield.text: Lesson 4: Session Layer
The Session layer controls the sessions between computers. It establishes, manages and terminates the connections between the local and remote application.

LI.FONT: The Session layer controls the sessions between computers.
It establishes, manages and terminates the connections between the local and remote application.

textfield.text: Lesson 5: Transport Layer
Till now, there is Session openning between the Sender and the Receiver But if the receiver is Openning more than one application, How the Sender direct the Data to the right Applcation ?

LI.FONT: Till now, there is Session openning between the Sender and the Receiver
But if the receiver is Openning more than one application, How the Sender direct the Data to the right Applcation ?

textfield.text: Organize data into segments Provide transparent transfer of data between hosts. It is usually responsible for end-to-end error recovery and flow control, and ensuring complete data transfer.

LI.FONT: Organize data into segments
Provide transparent transfer of data between hosts.
It is usually responsible for end-to-end error recovery and flow control, and ensuring complete data transfer.

textfield.text: Lesson 6: Network Layer
Data in Network Layer is converted into a Packet, which is: Segment + Header Network Layer has a Logical Address (IP Address) Header carries Source IP Address, and Destination IP Address

LI.FONT: Data in Network Layer is converted into a Packet, which is: Segment + Header
Network Layer has a Logical Address (IP Address)
Header carries Source IP Address, and Destination IP Address

textfield.text: Lesson 7: Data Link Layer
Responsible for organizing data into Frames, by adding Header. Header holds Source Mac Address, and Destination Mac Address. Trailer holds the result of CRC: Cycle Redundancy Check.

LI.FONT: Responsible for organizing data into Frames, by adding Header.
Header holds Source Mac Address, and Destination Mac Address.
Trailer holds the result of CRC: Cycle Redundancy Check.

textfield.text: Switch is a network device that lets different noeds to communicate with each other without slowing them down.

P.FONT: Switch is a network device that lets different noeds to communicate with each other without slowing them down.

textfield.text: Lesson 8: Physical Layer

Defines all the Electrical and Physical Specifications for Devices. The Most basic Network Layer, providing only the means of Transmitting raw bits through any types of Cables Network device in Physical layer is: Hub, which is NOT Smart enough!

LI.FONT: Defines all the Electrical and Physical Specifications for Devices.
The Most basic Network Layer, providing only the means of Transmitting raw bits through any types of Cables
Network device in Physical layer is: Hub, which is NOT Smart enough!

textfield.text: Chapter 3: Network Protocols and Devices
Lesson 1: Network Communication and Protocols

Protocols are needed for Computer Networks to Communicate efficiently. They are set of rules that enable data to fall from one NIC to another. Protocols control the messages origination, messages end, and messages quantity in the network. There are Four Major Networking Protocols.

LI.FONT: Protocols are needed for Computer Networks to Communicate efficiently.
They are set of rules that enable data to fall from one NIC to another.
Protocols control the messages origination, messages end, and messages quantity in the network.
There are Four Major Networking Protocols.

textfield.text: NetBios: Common Protocol that allows Applications in LAN to communicate It doesn't Support: Routing Mechanism Originally Developed by IBM (for LAN Manager) Obtained by Microsoft for Windows NT and LAN Manager NetBEUI: NetBIOS Extended User Interface. This is an enhanced version of the NetBIOS protocol used by network operating systems (NOS), such as Microsoft's Windows NT. Non-routable

LI.FONT: NetBios: Common Protocol that allows Applications in LAN to communicate
It doesn't Support: Routing Mechanism
Originally Developed by IBM (for LAN Manager)
Obtained by Microsoft for Windows NT and LAN Manager
NetBEUI: NetBIOS Extended User Interface.
This is an enhanced version of the NetBIOS protocol used by network operating systems (NOS), such as Microsoft's Windows NT.
Non-routable

textfield.text: Apple Talk: Set of LAN Communication Protocols Supports up to 32 Devices

P.FONT: Apple Talk: Set of LAN Communication Protocols

textfield.text: Lesson 2: Protocols in OSI Model
Lesson 1: Collision Domain and Broadcast Domain

P.FONT: Lesson 1: Collision Domain and Broadcast Domain

textfield.text: Collision Domain: Consists of all Devices that can see or involved in a Collision. All the stations informed by any collision as in Hub: all Ports are in a Collision Domain

LI.FONT: Collision Domain: Consists of all Devices that can see or involved in a Collision.
All the stations informed by any collision
as in Hub: all Ports are in a Collision Domain

textfield.text: Broadcast Domain: it consists of all devices that can see Broadcast. Router Separates Broadcast Domains

LI.FONT: Broadcast Domain: it consists of all devices that can see Broadcast.
Router Separates Broadcast Domains
